column1: Dr Tweetie Pie gets backing from parents and children;"Study shows white coat not the best choice for pediatricians

Pediatricians should drop the white doctors' coats and wear T-shirts with cartoon characters instead according to a study carried out at the Medi-Uni Graz in Austria and published in Acta Paediatrica. Doctors were alternately asked to wear three different clothing types while dealing with child patients
column2: the traditional white lab coat with a shirt and tie
column3: or a smart white polo T-shirt and finally a dark blue casual T-shirt complete with the cartoon character Tweetie Pie.One hundred and seven children and 72 parents were visited by the paediatrician randomly wearing one of the three different outfits (casual
column4: semiformal
column5: formal) during their hospital stay. To her surprise Julia Hofmann
column6: who carried out the study for her doctorate degree
column7: found that the doctor with the casual clothing was not only more popular with the kids
column8: but also with the parents.She said: ""There were two aims of the project
column9: to find out what clothing the children preferred on their doctors
column10: and also to see which style installed the most professional trust in parents."" Parents were questioned after each visit
column11: and she said: ""The most interesting thing is that the doctor wearing a T-shirt with a cartoon character did not result in a loss of trust among parents."" Using a 'likert scale'
column12: the casual outfit received the best mark by 95.5% of parents (58.3% in the semiformal
column13: 30.8% in the formal group). The degree of the parents' trust in the paediatrician was comparable in all three groups. And the vast majority - 75 per cent - were in favour of the doctors wearing more colourful clothing.For the children a third of the kids aged between 6 and 18 said they preferred the cartoon character look with a 100 per cent in favour
column14: whereas for children under 6 the clothing the doctor wore was regarded as irrelevant. In conclusion author Hofmann said that it was clear that ""parents do not only tolerate a casual outfit
column15: they even prefer it without any loss of trust. The same holds true for children between 6 and 18 years. For younger children
column16: the paediatricians' outfit seems to play no major role.""The study will reignite debate about the doctor's choice of clothing after the American Medical Association agreed there was a need to reconsider whether doctors' wore their iconic white lab coats
column17: citing evidence that the garment contributes to the spread of infection.Several studies have shown that the coats harbour potentially harmful bacteria. It is also blamed for ""white coat hypertension""
column18: the name given to the very common condition occurring in up to 20% of patients in which a person's blood pressure is abnormally elevated when it is measured in the doctor's office
